description.narrative: Increased support of parents for the SRHR of their children

Malawi’s population is predominantly rural and youthful. 84,7% of the young people lives in rural areas. Assessments carried out in the health sector unveil that only one third of youth have heard of Youth Friendly Sexual and Reproductive Health Services (YF(SR)HS) and only 13% are accessing these services (YFHS Evaluation, 2014). The 2016 baseline study of Empowering Young People (EYP) project, discloses the main barriers for young people to seek YFSR S services: 1) lack of confidentiality of health personnel; 2) lack of money for transportation and services; 3) poor comprehensive knowledge on HIV and the available SRH services; 4) concern that parents will be judgmental and non-supportive while at the same time young people value the opinion and support of their parents.This project is a follow up to the Healthy Young People project which focused on the first 3 obstacles mentioned. It will work on the 4th, eg improving the knowledge, attitude, and skills of parents regarding SRHR in order to increase their support for young people, their SRHR and the uptake of YF(SR)HS.

This project is a follow up of the Healthy Young People (HYP) project (2014-2016) working towards the improvement of the Sexual & Reproductive Health & Rights of young people (10-24 years). Young people are concerned that their parents will diaprove and judge while they do value the support of their parents. This project will focus on increasing this support.

title.narrative: Number of parents with increased scores on their KAP (Knowledge, Attitudes and Skills)
Number of parents that support their children to access CSE and YFHS
